title: Permanent bans not very effective on free to play games.
body:
As someone who has received multiple permanent bans over multiple games, I feel I am a somewhat self taught expert on the matter. 

Ill start by pointing out the flaw in chat restrictions. Its pretty much go play 10 games of ARAM. No one learns anything from them. It is just a temporary mute button for a few players. You just play 10 short matches and go back to being toxic in ranked. The goal of them is to get rid of them as soon as possible. A minor inconvenience.

Next is the permaban. When I log on and find a permaban waiting for me (not just on LoL), I laugh about it, relive the good times thanks to reform cards, (lookin' at you Rito Lyte <3) and make a new account. Get it to 30 in a week, and back to being toxic. The only thing I learn from permanent bans is "Less micro-transactions, this is only a temporary account". Permanently banning someone and wondering why they don't change is similar to wondering why people jailed for life without parole don't change. You've done your worst. That's the biggest punishment you can do. Take away our account. We just make another one, knowing that there is nothing you can do to stop it. The worst part about being permanently banned is having to think of a new name.

(By the way it would be sweet if perma-banned accounts got their names taken away to free up some names, consider it babes)

 There was even a time I would have 2-3 level 30 accounts sitting, waiting for that day when I get the permanent ban. 30 seconds later I'd be back on the Rift, only difference is, having just lost an account I was pissed off and more volatile towards players.

However if I find that I have been banned for 14 days, I spend those 14 days waiting to regain access to my account, because it isn't worth leveling a new character/account for only a few days of play time. In that time, I have time to reconsider my actions and it actually feels like a punishment. It is always on your mind, you sit there wondering what game to play and if you have a craving for some Summoner's Rift, you can't play it.

They send criminals to jail with a chance of parole to invoke a change. They can use their time away from society to change their behavior and become a model citizen. You can use the same in games. I believe that 30/60/90 day bans have more impact on toxic players than a perma-ban does. You need to break the habit of abusing people, and permanent bans don't do this. 

Toxic players are degenerates. We are lazy, but also determined. We can get a new account to 30 within a week, but we probably won't level a new account if we know we can get our accounts back after a month or two. Who knows, maybe in those months we might mature enough to start respecting our fellow summoner, but we certainly won't mature very quickly in the 30 seconds it takes to recreate an account. All we learn is "don't buy Riot Points cause we can lose our accounts at any time."

A decent method of re-education would be a parole system of sorts. Give people a reason to change. People who have received lengthy bans (90 - permanent) could have the opportunity to redeem their accounts by participating in a trial period. The trial period would only be shown to the player. The player would then play a games with other summoners in good standing (players rarely reported, often honored).
 If the player successfully plays for a predetermined period without becoming toxic, they would redeem their account.  If the players fails to be civil and receives a report, the report would be investigated and decided upon. If the report was valid, that account is permanently thrown into oblivion. If the report was unwarranted, the account continues with the trial. This method forces the toxic player to undergo a time period where they would be exposed to only good behavior, breaking their habit of abuse. This would be a one time offer, for obvious reasons.

Give toxic players a reason to change. Make them use their time away from the Rift for something more than leveling an alternate account.

That's how I see it anyway, and I can safely assume I have experienced these punishments more than most people.

replies.body: Surprisingly not a bad argument.
Its probably time they rethink permabans here anyway, since there is now precedent for software being defined as goods in Australia.

Digital purchases (including in games) were always protected by consumer law. 
On top of this, players already do chargebacks whenever they're banned. Riot's response to chargebacks is to ban your account until you pay the value of the amount owed, bit useless when you're already perma banned... 

(note: Not encouraging anyone to ever do this - in other countries you may still legally owe Riot the monies charged back. In Australia it's technically legal under Australian Consumer Law, though if you are intending to do this you should seek your own legal advice instead of considering my above statements as solid advice - your best bet is to simply not get banned)

Source:
www.twitch.tv/loltyler1 (admits often that he's done chargebacks on ALL the RP purchases ever made on his 15+ banned accounts)
https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201753334-Chargebacks "the account remains frozen until the player manually repays the balance."
or you can simply learn how to shut the fuck up
Agree with your sentiment generally but I dont think it addresses the problem the OP raises.

I do have to agree with this.
I've been permabanned on 3 accounts (including this one) but I just make a new one and continue on.
I for myself am toxic when ppl just ignore suggestions or flame. I know ppl say to mute, but no point in muting if the other person still feeds or trolls.

For me it almost became "well if you can't beat them, join them" but I've learned to just remain calm and not care about my rank so much.

In the sense of a permaban, I love the message on the screen when you get it (along the lines of) "the community doesn't want your bad behaviour" but it takes me 1 min to make another account and continue on.
You don't fix anything, if anything you make it worse, because after the 4th time making an account and lvling, you get good at it, and it's actually less of a deterrent as it gets easier and easier every time.

The things that did work for me is the chat restrictions and the ban for 14/30 days.

I would actually make it that a chat restriction means you get 0 chats per game... or maybe 1 every 10min.

The problem with toxicity is there needs to be a want to do well, and as long as there isn't one there won't be any less trolls or toxicity.
you might spread it out a bit by getting them to make another account, but it won't stop.

Just my 2 cents.

>You don't fix anything, if anything you make it worse, because after the 4th time making an account and lvling, you get good at it, and it's actually less of a deterrent as it gets easier and easier every time.


Exactly.

The game has come a long way since I started playing. In 2009, you would expect at least 1 afk every 2 games. People would abuse everything you did and even with a majority of the players being new to LoL or even MOBAS in general, you would get trolled or expected to know the game. Exploiting and cheating was common. The 'no summoner cooldowns' cheat or the immortal karthus exploit was ruining the game.

They've done well to kill as many weeds as they can, but you'll find that those players that simply make new accounts will get tired of having to start over and over again.

Maybe for some. I only play a handful of champs anyway, so starting again is pretty easy when I only need to buy Brand and Twisted Fate. :P

You raise a good point lads. I also think that reports should have different levels of value, because as Mickey Knox said, a tumblr kid who reports someone for using the wrong 'their' that reports at least one person every game should not make the same amount of difference as a person like me that really only reports someone once every maybe 20 games. 

And I agree with what JHAEL and SoftHardcore11 said as well. Instead of banning people outright, just segregate them from the non-toxic players. A little personal queue that forces players to be healthy additions to the league community. I sure as hell would try to get out of that queue as soon as possible if I was put into it. 

Playing with toxicity is not fun, and permabans simply do not fix that.

It is an interesting conundrum.

There was a saying back in the day that the kids who got the cane at school would never learn from it,  and the kids who would learn from it never got it (because they behaved well already).

I have  invested time and money into my account and getting a permaban would likely put me off the game for good.  So although i can be rude to intentional feeders or incredibad players from time to time i don't go all out and as a matter of account preservation i don't feed or troll. I am probably the sort of paying customer riot wants to retain because i am a source of revenue and i fear the consequence of a permaban (ie money and time down the drain).

Contrast to someone who has 4 accounts with no financial investment - they dgaf if one account gets banned as they will just log in with another. 

So in essence the punishment system may be ineffective as the people who deserve bans don't give a fuck and the people who have invested heavily generally won't be dicks.  But if you catch the 2nd category on a bad day then they are unlikely to continue playing whereas if you catch the first they'll be back on the rift in 5 mins in a bad mood. 

Interesting dilemma.

I have had five accounts to date.
I have invested well over 3000 hours and well over 3000 dollars on the game.
I lose account, I make another, I just won't spend as much the next run through. Especially with Hextrash crafting out, I can usually pick up a champ or two for free.
That is insanity.  You must have a lot of cash to burn.

Not really. I have played this game since season 2, so that is almost five years of LoL.

$600 a year isn't that much when you don't like other people.
Yeah i started in late 2009 but that is still a shit load of cash to burn.  Being polite costs nothing but being toxic costs $600/year. Interesting approach you take.

In a certain game I played a few years ago, there's this thing called "Prisoner Isles" which is basically a realm in the game where cheaters, flamers, and overall toxic players get sent to. I think league should have a similar system, it should have something like get queued with only people that have like, report strikes or something. Or if you really wanna destroy their mental state to reform somehow. If they play a game they get queued with bots on the enemy team, and their own team. The bots are programmed to continuously flame him and troll and feed and the enemy team is like, super buffed and unbeatable and flame him for every mistake, of course that would be hard to program I think so they should have limited play time so actual people can treat them this way, and when the match ends they can't report or block them. Fighting fire with fire will be a great option here and because of this thing called pride this will take a while on some players.

Perhaps it is best if "permabanned" players get drafted with each other on the same team.  I have a feeling there is no shortage of "members" (waiting time might be just that little bit higher), and OBVIOUSLY they'd have a much higher win rate because they are all at "challenjour" level. We don't get to play with them on the same team. I think it's a win-win. They'd have so much fun out-trolling each other and out-humiliating each other. The all chat would be glorious.

Let me start by pointing out that there is a big difference between people banned for their actions and people banned for their comments.

People banned for comments don't **directly** lose the game.
Abusive comments **indirectly** lose the game but only as a result of the unstable people the insult is directed at. The comments are merely a catalyst.
A salty player would have a lesser effect on a team of functioning adults than they would on a team of tumblr kids. If you spent more time focusing on the majority of your screen, rather than the chat box, you would find you win a lot more.


I personally would not mind having a team of people who have been punished for being abusive, because my skin isn't paper thin. I am not prone to breaking down and crying when someone I will never meet calls me names, because I use my big boy brain to determine what is worth reading and what isn't. Sift through the insults to find out valuable information. That is part of being a grown up. You can't expect the world to mollycoddle you forever.

I truly believe that change is needed for the league community to become civil again. 
_**Change on both sides**_.
Toxic players need to learn to respect their fellow summoners, but crybaby report-bots need to learn to ignore them and move on. Until the whiny half of the server grows up, there will never be peace, they will just find something else to cry about. This is not to say that sensitive players are the reason toxicity exists, but they exaggerate the situation to an unhealthy extent, which only clouds the issue.

First we will slowly remove all of the people making racist and homophobic slurs.
Then we will slowly remove all of the people putting others down.
Then we will start to ban people who swear too often.
Then we start to ban people who don't speak with correct grammar.

Where does it end? Having the report feature gives the power to the community, which is good. What the majority of the community finds undesirable, will slowly get punished out. The problem with this, is that something else will take it's place as the most re portable act. So even though swearing doesn't seem like an issue, that is only because **comparatively** it isn't as bad as racial remarks. 

Until you accept that there will always be abusive people in the world, you will never fix the problem.
You're fighting an imaginary enemy.

30/60/90 day suspensions would do nothing. As you said, you will just level another acc during this time and probably have multiple sitting there waiting. Only now after 30/60/90 days it will become available again, and history says you won't reform.

Not at all, If I had a 30 day ban I wouldn't waste a week levelling another, and most people don't have backup accounts.  

If I knew that there was a chance I could get back my account for reforming I would make a serious effort at it. 

The worst punishment they can deal out is a minor inconvenience. They need to start encouraging reform.
